CZ จาก Binance: 'ไม่มีใครสามารถบงการ Bitcoin ได้'

Binance's CZ: 'No One Manipulates Bitcoin'

2d ago//Arman Shirinyan
bitcoin
AI

Summary

TH

ชางเผิงเจ้า (CZ) ผู้ก่อตั้งบิแนนซ์ ได้ปฏิเสธข้อกล่าวหาเกี่ยวกับการปั่นราคา Bitcoin โดยอ้างว่าแผนกตลาดที่รุนแรงราวเดือนตุลาคมเกิดจากปัจจัยเศรษฐศาสตร์มหาศาสตร์ เช่น การประกาศอัตราภาษีมากกว่าการปั่นราคาเป็นการจงใจ เขายังเน้นว่าการเปลี่ยนแปลงราคา Bitcoin จะต้องใช้เงินทุนในระดับที่น้อยคนจะกล้าลงทุน โดยเฉพาะอย่างยิ่งเมื่อ Bitcoin มีมูลค่าหลายล้านล้านดอลลาร์แล้ว ชางเผิงเจ้ายังชี้ให้เห็นถึงการควบคุมทางกฎหมายอย่างแข็งแรงของบิแนนซ์ ซึ่งทำให้การกระทำที่ไม่ถูกต้องทราบระดับแลกเปลี่ยนเป็นเรื่องที่เป็นไปไม่ได้

EN

Binance founder Changpeng Zhao (CZ) refuted allegations of Bitcoin price manipulation, attributing market crashes to macroeconomic factors like tariff announcements rather than intentional manipulation. He argued that altering Bitcoin's price would require capital on a scale few actors would dare to deploy, especially given Bitcoin's status as a multitrillion-dollar asset class. CZ also emphasized Binance's robust regulatory oversight and compliance structure, noting that misconduct would be nearly impossible under such scrutiny. The article presents a nuanced view, agreeing that long-term manipulation is difficult in Bitcoin's decentralized market, but acknowledging that short-term price movements can be influenced by large funds through mechanisms like leveraged liquidations and concentrated liquidity moves.

Key Points

  • CZ refutes Bitcoin manipulation claims, attributing market crashes to macroeconomic factors
  • Zhao argues Bitcoin's size makes long-term manipulation infeasible due to enormous capital requirements
  • While long-term manipulation is difficult, short-term price movements can be influenced by large funds through mechanisms like leveraged liquidations and concentrated liquidity moves

Article

Cover image via U.Today Disclaimer: The opinions expressed by our writers are their own and do not represent the views of U.Today. The financial and market information provided on U.Today is intended for informational purposes only. U.Today is not liable for any financial losses incurred while trading cryptocurrencies. Conduct your own research by contacting financial experts before making any investment decisions. We believe that all content is accurate as of the date of publication, but certain offers mentioned may no longer be available. Changpeng Zhao, the founder of Binance, recently refuted allegations that big players or major exchanges intentionally manipulate the price of Bitcoin. In a Jan. 31, AMA, Zhao contended that macroeconomic news — more specifically, a tariff announcement — rather than exchange failures or concerted manipulation, caused the severe market crash occurring around Oct. 10. CZ's point of view He also emphasized that neither he nor Binance directly profits from cryptocurrency trading, and that purposefully altering the price of Bitcoin would require capital on a scale few actors would dare to deploy. Zhao claims that since Bitcoin is now essentially a multitrillion-dollar asset class, sustained manipulation is not feasible, as manipulators would face enormous financial risk if they attempted to significantly alter the market. BTC/USDT Chart by TradingView He further highlighted Binance’s regulatory oversight , particularly its compliance structure and monitoring arrangements, arguing that misconduct at the exchange level would be nearly impossible under such scrutiny. While reminding participants that no technological system can guarantee perfect uptime, he noted that users impacted by previous system outages were compensated. HOT Stories Bitcoin's liquidity Zhao has a point, but the circumstances are more complex. Because of Bitcoin’s high liquidity and widespread use, manipulating the asset on a long-term, global scale is extremely difficult. In a decentralized, fiercely competitive market, no single exchange or trader can maintain price control indefinitely. You Might Also Like Short-term price impact, however, is a different story, as leveraged liquidations, concentrated liquidity moves and strategic order placement are common ways that large funds, whales and institutional traders influence price action. Bitcoin’s market structure often features liquidity sweeps, stop-loss hunting and cascades of liquidations, particularly when leverage is high, and while these actions may not constitute outright manipulation, they still allow wealthy participants to create favorable entry and exit conditions. Recent price movements support this interpretation. Following a wave of liquidations and panic-selling, Bitcoin fell into the mid-$70,000 range, indicating that leveraged positions were flushed out rather than that a single actor was forcing price movement. When leverage declines, markets frequently overshoot in both directions.
